profile.name: Alvaro
profile.title: CTO at Ahana Pediatrics
profile.description:
Informático por vocación.
Hago software desde hace algo más de una década, tanto en consultoría como en producto.
Me encanta mi trabajo y el constante aprendizaje que requiere, tanto en su faceta tecnológica como humana.
Algunas empresas en las que he trabajo son Autentia, Digibis, TwoToForty y actualmente en Klikin y Waylet.

interestingFacts.fact: TRS-80 Model I with Level I BASIC and 4K of RAM

recommendations.title: TCP/IP Illustrated, Vol. 1: The Protocols (Addison-Wesley Professional Computin...
recommendations.summary: The TCP layer is an amazingly sophisticated and robust protocol design that was refined and improved based on significant field experience. It's not until you completely understand all its nuances do you realize that if/when you set out to design a protocol of your own that the problem being solved is easily underestimated and not for the faint of heart.

recommendations.title: TCP/IP Illustrated, Vol. 2: The Implementation
recommendations.summary: I wish the authors of the original BSD TCP/IP network stack had read Code Complete. Without this volume, the implementation would be totally unmaintainable. As a side note, I have always wanted to sit down and write a modern implementation of the stack from scratch...and someday may.

recommendations.title: Code Complete (Microsoft Programming)
recommendations.summary: Writing code good is first about the next person to come along and only second about the computer executing it. Therefore, just because it works, doesn't mean you are done or that you couldn't have done it better.

recommendations.title: Competing for the Future
recommendations.summary: While there are no crystal balls, you can imagine a future and do the hard work to make it come true.

recommendations.title: The Passionate Programmer: Creating a Remarkable Career in Software Development...
The Pragmatic Programmer: From Journeyman to Master
Code Complete: A Practical Handbook of Software Construction, Second Edition
recommendations.summary:
This book is somewhat dated, with no JavaScript sample code and plenty of Visual Basic sample code. However, I'd recommend it a source of inspiration to software engineers looking to form ideas about how best to write code. Some of McConnell's ideas are great, some are pretty terrible; some of his examples are useful, some are total strawmen.

It's a hefty tome, but it's worth going through; just take it with a pinch of salt and you'll do fine.

recommendations.title: Switch: How to Change Things When Change Is Hard
Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software

challenges.description:
Executive in charge of the definition and operations of the revenue bearing products and services of the Stack Exchange Network including our flagship property StackOverflow.com. Responsibilities include running the advertising business and the also the Careers business that this very profile is hosted on.

Our mission is making the Internet a better place than we found it and to enable experts to get answers to their questions from other experts via our community powered (and free!) Q&A sites: it started with Stack Overflow for programming related questions, but now we’ve moved on to dozens of other topics via our Stack Exchange network. See what we are all about at StackExchange.com/about.

Technical leader of Kodak's top digital photographic copy and enlargement systems including the highly successful Kodak PictureMaker kiosk system commonly seen in many department stores.

Proposed product concept, developed market attack strategy, and defined system requirements for the initial line of products that eventually evolved into a major new business.

Leader of all software development during the product commercialization cycle.

Software development focused on image path definition, imaging algorithm optimization, print engine controller, touch screen GUI window operating system.

From concept to world-wide product launch in less than 11 months.

Co-founded the company in 1998 and built the business to the point of a successful exit when Allworx was acquired by PAETEC (NASDAQ:PAET) in October 2007. Allworx now operates as a wholly owned subsidiary of PAETEC Holding Company.

Senior executive responsible for the strategic direction of the Allworx business and driving the ongoing integration of Allworx with the offerings from the other business units of PAETEC. Leader of all product development including product strategy, product definition and product requirements for the entire Allworx product portfolio.

Structured Allworx into two successful business divisions: The Consulting Division offering embedded product development services to other companies; the Product Division designing, manufacturing, and selling a complete line of VoIP based telephone phones and phone systems.

The Allworx product family includes three web managed VoIP PBX switch products, seven VoIP telephone handsets, and a suite of Windows applications.

roles.name: System Architect and Technical Program Manager

challenges.description:
Recruited and lead 15 person engineering team responsible for a new line of embedded print servers (raster image processors) for all Xerox Engineering Systems printer and plotter products.

Defined all system requirements, system architecture and created the product technical road map for the next generation of solutions. Achieved a 10X product performance improvement at approximately ½ the cost of the targeted competition.

Met or beat all projected metrics relative to budget, schedule, unit costs and performance.

First iteration of the new platform was developed completely from scratch in less than 12 months. The highly successful Xerox 8830 wide format printer/plotter product received Cadalyst Magazine's highest 5-star rating.

I was responsible for creating and maintaining the tools used by IBM Support Engineers at all levels supporting IBM's SAN Volume Controller and Storwize V7000 products.

These tools provide visualization of data sets as well as automatic problem diagnosis.

Without these tools, lower level engineers are forced to escalate tickets to higher levels, putting a burden on limited resources. My responsibility is to provide easily usable tools to allow engineers to spend less time combing through data and more time figuring out diagnoses and resolutions.

Our logs and dumps are in a proprietary format, so I need to craft everything from scratch. One of my accomplishments is to study data visualization techniques (from the likes of Tufte) and bring them to bear in the field of Technical Support.

*   Developed firmware and hardware for DMX-512 [transceiver module](http://www.farnell.com/datasheets/461029.pdf).
    *   Converted _from_ DMX-512 to voltage/servo/RS-232
    *   Converted _to_ DMX-512 from RS-232/voltage
*   Taught self SPI, RS232, DMX and PWM protocols from specification sheets.
*   Wrote end user documentation.
*   Developed GUIs for company's modules using Visual Basic for Windows UIs and NS Basic

I run the Product Engineering team at Jellyvision, working on [ALEX](http://www.meetalex.com/), the virtual benefits counsellor.

We're rolling out Scrum at Jellyvision and working to get the team less siloed and working together more closely on full stack features and fixes. We've got some outstanding engineers here and helping them communicate and collaborate well is what I'm focussed on.

I'm responsible for recruiting new talent and helping our current talent grow.

Onsite Support for Ford Motor Credit Company
--------------------------------------------

Acted as the on-site expert for a significant migration of data from a competitor. Streamlined Ford's configuration methods to reduce errors.

Worked directly and proactively with Ford management and engineering teams to address emerging issues.

Designed and presented educational packages to fellow engineers on support tools and debug techniques.

IBM TotalStorage support
------------------------

Provided Level 2 and Level 3 support for IBM TotalStorage products: \* SAN Volume Controller \* Subsystem Device Driver \* DS CIM Agent

Presented on SAN Volume Controller at two conferences and to multiple customers

Acted as Lab Advocate for Kroger during a major transitional period as they adopted our products.

Developed a critical support tool for analyzing system configurations.

Worked in the Storage Subsystem Department on two storage cards

SCSI/SSA Protocol Converter Card
--------------------------------

Developed in Assembler, but using module-based approach. I owned the SCSI half of the codebase.

I introduced support for compressed microcode builds. In addition, I resolved a number of _long_\-standing defects that had been implicated in multiple customer issues.

Participated in a focussed effort to debug issues affecting multiple customers and successfully isolated the root cause of the error.

FC-AL Storage Adapter
---------------------

Developed in C, but using OO design and implementation methods, eg UML.

Developed code runs in an in-house Real Time Operating System

Built Korn Shell scripts to automate code reviews, change management and unit testing.

roles.name: Global Support Manager, JP Morgan Chase Account

challenges.description:
This role involved

*   Account Management
*   Change Management
*   Problem Management
*   Crisis Management

In short, I was responsible for all IBM Storage problems at JPMorgan Chase. My job was to redcue the number of outages that occurred, with appropriate change management and deployment schedules. In addition I was to reduce the length of any outages by ensuring that the right resources were deployed in the event of a failure.

I was very effective within this role and won the praise of high level manahement within IBM and JPMorgan Chase

Completed three versions of our product, [Pepper](http://www.vodori.com/pepper.html).

Implemented code quality improvements:

*   Championed the use of code reviews
*   Implemented a JavaScript Unit Test strategy
*   Introduced a reading group to encourage growth of junior developers
*   Refined ticket workflow processes to ensure that due care was taken over fixes
*   Implemented the first significant roll out of the Scrum methodology in the company
*   Devised and delivered JavaScript training across the company (with a focus on Dojo)
    *   Built a CI platform and build farm based on Atlassian's Bamboo product

Major part of the FE recruitment process, performing phone screens, technical interviews and on-site interviews.

Provided technical and professional mentorship to developers both in my team and across the company.

details.name: Background
details.description:
When I reflect on my experience, the thing that always occurs to me is Patterns.

I've always enjoyed Improv Comedy. From the age of 12, I've been messing around on stage, playing pattern games (unwittingly, at the time) with friends. Even now, nearly 2 decades on, I'm still doing it; I've been taking Improv classes for a little over 2 years now and performing with troups and in festivals for the past year and it's all about spotting an developing patterns to comedic effect.

The same is true of my study of Physics. I took that course for the sole reason that I just love the subject. Physics is all about spotting patterns and developing models. I still recall the moment when I realised that 90% of Physics is basically waves, such that the equations that describe light passing through glass also explain why wine cellars stay at a constant temperature. Life got a whole lot easier when I figured that out.

In all, I love anything that is about finding hidden patterns and underlying, fundamental models that describe seemingly disparate phenomena. It's why I love improv, it's why I love crosswords and it's why I love software development.
